epistemological_foundation_schema.description: Complete epistemological foundation template capturing paradigm, ontology, epistemology, theoretical framework, and justification

paradigm.description: High-level analytical paradigm or philosophical approach
examples: Bayesian Evidential Reasoning
Structural Causal Models (Pearl 2000, 2009) combined with Bayesian probability
Systems Thinking + Bayesian Risk Aggregation
Gender-Responsive Budgeting Analysis
Hierarchical Bayesian Causal Inference
Pearl's Ladder of Causation (Level 3: Counterfactuals)
Robustness Testing in Causal Inference
Neyman-Pearson Frequentist Hypothesis Testing
Effect Size Estimation and Practical Significance
Bayesian Epistemology - Coherent Belief Updating
Decision Theory + Operational Research
Neural Named Entity Recognition (BiLSTM-CRF)
Dependency Grammar + Pattern Matching
Frame Semantics + Semantic Role Labeling (SRL)
paradigm.pattern: Paradigm name + (optional reference) + concise description of approach

ontological_basis.description: What exists/what is real in the domain; the nature of entities and phenomena being analyzed
examples: Structural Causal Models (Pearl 2000, 2009) combined with Bayesian probability for policy operationalization gaps
Policy failure theory (Bovens & 't Hart 1996) - cascading omissions create systemic implementation failure
Feminist economics - budget allocations reveal policy priorities; absence = structural neglect (Elson 2006)
Generative causal mechanisms (Pearl 2009, Spirtes et al. 2000) - policies operate via latent mechanisms
Counterfactual semantics via twin networks - evaluates alternative histories
Statistical significance testing for claim contradictions - null hypothesis: claims are consistent
Organizational capabilities exist as semi-structured textual mentions of institutional actors
Entities are syntactic constituents identifiable by dependency relations

epistemological_stance.description: How knowledge is acquired and validated; the theory of knowledge underlying the method
examples: Critical Bayesian - assumes municipal plans are incomplete by default, uses priors from Colombian PDM corpus analysis
Holistic-systemic - omissions are not independent; missing baseline data cascades into unmeasurable outcomes
Critical feminist - assumes gender blindness in budgets until proven otherwise
Abductive-probabilistic - infers best explanation for observed policy gaps using hierarchical priors
Interventionist causality - simulates counterfactual policy states via SCM manipulation
Modal realism for policy - possible worlds semantics applied to policy outcomes
Skeptical-empirical - assumes unobserved confounders exist, tests how robust findings are
Falsificationist (Popper) - seeks to reject consistency hypothesis via evidence
Pragmatic - statistical significance ≠ practical importance; focuses on real-world impact
Subjectivist Bayesian - probabilities represent degrees of belief given evidence
Consequentialist - evaluates policies by outcomes, losses measured in unrealized welfare gains
Supervised learning epistemology: entity knowledge induced from annotated corpora
Rule-based linguistic epistemology: entity knowledge derived from syntactic structure
epistemological_stance.pattern: Epistemological school/tradition + methodological assumptions + validation approach

theoretical_framework.description: Foundational academic references and theoretical constructs supporting the method
examples: Pearl (2000) 'Causality' - SCM formalism for causal mechanism representation
Good (1950) 'Probability and the Weighing of Evidence' - Bayesian weight of evidence
Van Evera (1997) 'Guide to Methods' - Hoop tests for necessary conditions in policy analysis
Lieberman (2015) 'Nested Analysis' - Multi-method causal inference integration
Perrow (1999) 'Normal Accidents' - tightly coupled systems magnify component failures
Dempster-Shafer Theory (1976) - belief propagation for cumulative uncertainty
Elson (2006) 'Budgeting for Women's Rights' - gender budget analysis methodology
Pearl (2009) 'Causality' Ch.7 - Structural Equation Models with latent variables
Pearl & Mackenzie (2018) 'Book of Why' - Ladder of Causation
Rosenbaum (2002) 'Observational Studies' - sensitivity analysis for hidden bias
Neyman & Pearson (1933) 'On the Problem of the Most Efficient Tests'
Cohen (1988) 'Statistical Power Analysis' - standardized effect sizes
Jaynes (2003) 'Probability Theory: Logic of Science' - MaxEnt priors
Gelman et al. (2013) 'Bayesian Data Analysis' - hierarchical modeling
Colombian Law 1257/2008 - Legal framework mandating gender policy structures
Lample et al. (2016) - Neural NER with BiLSTM-CRF
March & Olsen (1984) - Logic of appropriateness: institutional actors
theoretical_framework.pattern: Author (Year) 'Title' - Specific contribution relevant to method

justification.description: Why this epistemological approach is appropriate for the specific question; connects paradigm to policy analysis needs
examples: Gender gap quantification (D1-Q2) requires detecting ABSENCE of evidence (data gaps, unrecognized biases). Bayesian approach models prior probability of rare evidence items, enabling quantification of omissions.

Q002 evaluates recognition of data gaps - systemic risk arises when multiple gaps go unacknowledged, creating blind spots in policy M&E. Method aggregates omission severity using Dempster-Shafer belief propagation across causal graph.
Q002 requires identifying unquantified gender gaps - financial allocation gaps signal lack of recognition of gender disparities.
Q002 requires detecting UNRECOGNIZED gaps - Bayesian mechanism inference identifies missing causal pathways in plan logic, revealing implicit data gaps.
Q002's causal claims (gap omission → implementation failure) rest on SCM assumptions - stability testing evaluates how sensitive conclusions are to unmodeled confounders.
Q002 requires integrating evidence from 10 prior methods with varying reliability - Bayesian aggregation weights each source by credibility, propagates uncertainty through posteriors.
Identifying responsible entities requires combining computational linguistics (NER) with institutional theory to distinguish mere mentions from actual responsible actors.
justification.pattern: Question requirement → methodological capability → why this paradigm addresses it

usage_guidelines.when_to_apply: Apply this template for methods requiring rigorous epistemological grounding, particularly Bayesian methods, causal inference, statistical testing, or domain-specific analytical frameworks
how_to_customize: Replace paradigm with specific method's analytical approach
Adapt ontological_basis to domain (policy, finance, institutions, text)
Select epistemological_stance matching method's knowledge acquisition process
Include 4-6 foundational references relevant to method
Write justification connecting question needs to paradigm capabilities
quality_indicators: Paradigm is named and attributed to foundational work
Ontological basis specifies what exists/is measurable in domain
Epistemological stance clarifies how method produces valid knowledge
Theoretical framework includes 4+ academic references with specific contributions
Justification explicitly links question requirements to paradigm strengths

q002_method_1_audit_direct_evidence.ontological_basis: Structural Causal Models (Pearl 2000, 2009) combined with Bayesian probability for policy operationalization gaps
q002_method_1_audit_direct_evidence.epistemological_stance: Critical Bayesian - assumes municipal plans are incomplete by default, uses priors from Colombian PDM corpus analysis
theoretical_framework: Pearl (2000) 'Causality' - SCM formalism for causal mechanism representation
Good (1950) 'Probability and the Weighing of Evidence' - Bayesian weight of evidence
Van Evera (1997) 'Guide to Methods' - Hoop tests for necessary conditions in policy analysis
Lieberman (2015) 'Nested Analysis' - Multi-method causal inference integration
q002_method_1_audit_direct_evidence.justification: Gender gap quantification (D1-Q2) requires detecting ABSENCE of evidence (data gaps, unrecognized biases). Bayesian approach models prior probability of rare evidence items (e.g., P(explicit_gender_bias_recognition) ≈ 0.15 in weak PDMs), enabling quantification of omissions.

q002_method_7_counterfactual_query.ontological_basis: Counterfactual semantics via twin networks - evaluates alternative histories (what if gap HAD been recognized?)
q002_method_7_counterfactual_query.epistemological_stance: Modal realism for policy - possible worlds semantics applied to policy outcomes
theoretical_framework: Pearl & Mackenzie (2018) 'Book of Why' - Ladder of Causation (association → intervention → counterfactuals)
Woodward (2003) 'Making Things Happen' - manipulationist account of causation
Bareinboim & Pearl (2016) 'Causal Inference and Data Fusion' - transportability of causal effects
q002_method_7_counterfactual_query.justification: Q002 evaluates whether gaps are recognized - counterfactual reasoning answers: 'If plan HAD quantified gender gap, would outcome measurability improve?' Critical for attributing implementation failure to diagnostic omissions.

q004_method_1_identify_responsible_entit.ontological_basis: Organizational capabilities exist as semi-structured textual mentions of institutional actors with specific responsibilities for gender policy management. Entities have ontological reality as named organizations (Secretarías, Comisarías) with identifiable functions.
q004_method_1_identify_responsible_entit.epistemological_stance: Hybrid NLP-Institutional epistemology: knowledge of responsible entities is acquired through computational extraction (spaCy NER, syntax parsing) validated against institutional theory (March & Olsen 1984 on organizational capabilities, DiMaggio & Powell 1983 on institutional isomorphism). Extraction confidence combines NER precision with entity type specificity.
theoretical_framework: March & Olsen (1984) - Logic of appropriateness: institutional actors have defined roles and responsibilities
DiMaggio & Powell (1983) - Institutional isomorphism: gender policy entities follow normative structures
Lample et al. (2016) - Neural NER with BiLSTM-CRF for entity boundary detection
Nadeau & Sekine (2007) - Fine-grained entity typing for organizational classification
Colombian Law 1257/2008 - Legal framework mandating gender policy institutional structures
q004_method_1_identify_responsible_entit.justification: Identifying responsible entities requires combining computational linguistics (NER) with institutional theory to distinguish mere mentions from actual responsible actors. This dual approach ensures both computational precision and domain-grounded validation.
